title: A 52-week,Multi-center,Randomized,Double-blind,Placebo-controlled,Parallel Group Study in Patients With Mild Alzheimer's Disease to Investigate the Safety and Tolerability of Repeated Subcutaneous Injections of CAD106
description_brief: This study will evaluate the safety and tolerability of repeated subcutaneous injections of CAD106 in patients with mid Alzheimer's disease
explanation_target: Reason: CAD106 is an active Aβ (amyloid‑β) immunotherapy — a vaccine designed to induce Aβ‑specific antibody responses while avoiding Aβ‑specific T‑cell activation, i.e., a biologic that targets Alzheimer’s pathology rather than a small‑molecule symptomatic agent. citeturn0search3turn0search2

Act (trial details & evidence): The described trial (52‑week, multicenter, randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled, repeated subcutaneous injections of CAD106 in mild AD) matches published clinical studies evaluating CAD106 for safety, tolerability and immunogenicity. CAD106 has been administered subcutaneously in 52‑week randomized studies and induced Aβ‑IgG responses in treated patients. citeturn0search1turn0search3

Act (drug type/mechanism): CAD106 comprises the Aβ1–6 peptide coupled to a Qβ virus‑like particle to stimulate peripheral anti‑Aβ antibody production and reduce brain amyloid — i.e., an active biologic vaccine targeting amyloid pathology. citeturn0search2turn0search6

Reflect: Given the intervention (an active Aβ vaccine) and the stated goal (safety/tolerability of repeated injections in AD patients), the correct category is 'disease-targeted biologic' because CAD106 is a biologic immunotherapy directed at Alzheimer’s pathology rather than a symptomatic cognitive enhancer or a neuropsychiatric treatment. No substantial ambiguity in the description suggests an alternative category. citeturn0search4turn0search5

Web search results used (key sources): PubMed/Lancet‑Neurol and related publications reporting CAD106 phase‑1/phase‑2 studies and long‑term follow‑up; first‑in‑human / mechanism descriptions noting Aβ1–6 conjugated to Qβ and safety/immunogenicity findings. (See cited sources above for details.) citeturn0search3turn0search1turn0search2turn0search4turn0search6
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests CAD106, which is an active immunotherapy (vaccine) designed to induce anti–amyloid-β (Aβ) antibody responses and thereby engage/reduce Aβ pathology in Alzheimer’s disease. citeturn1search6turn1search1

Act: The trial description (52-week, randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled, repeated subcutaneous injections of CAD106 in mild AD) matches clinical studies of CAD106. CAD106 is composed of the Aβ1–6 peptide conjugated to a Qβ virus‑like particle to stimulate peripheral Aβ‑specific IgG production (active Aβ vaccine). Clinical studies report induced Aβ‑IgG responses and biomarker/ PET engagement. citeturn0search1turn1search0turn1search4

Reflect: The intervention specifically targets amyloid‑β (an established CADRO category A). There is no indication the trial’s primary mechanism targets tau, inflammation, neurotransmission, or multi-target biology; therefore the most specific CADRO match is 'A) Amyloid beta'. The cited publications and trial registries support the vaccine mechanism, composition (Aβ1–6 + Qβ) and immunogenicity/safety focus. citeturn1search1turn0search8
- Winblad et al. / Alzheimer's & Dementia (first-in-man description: CAD106 = Aβ1–6 coupled to Qβ; 52‑week study details). citeturn1search0
- Preclinical/mechanism paper (CAD106 Aβ1–6 + Qβ reduces amyloid in APP transgenic mice). citeturn1search1
- Phase 2 / Phase 2b and long-term clinical reports showing immunogenicity (Aβ‑IgG), safety/tolerability and PET/biomarker engagement. citeturn1search2turn0search8
- Clinical trial registry entries for the 52‑week repeated subcutaneous injections study (NCT00795418 / NCT00733863 and trial listings). citeturn0search2turn0search1
